citation.article-title: Taxonomic studies on Arthrobacter nicotianae and related taxa: description of Arthrobacter uratoxydans sp. nov. and Arthrobacter sulfureus sp. nov. and reclassification of Brevibacterium protophormiae as Arthrobacter protophormiae comb. nov.

p.s: Description of Arthrobacter uratoxydans sp. nov.
Arthrobacter uratoxydans (U.ra.to'xy.dans M.L. n. uratum salt of uric acid; M.L. part. oxydans oxidizing; M.L. part. uratoxydans uric acid oxidizing)
The description given below is taken from the original description of Sugisaki et. al., 1973; US patent No. 3.767.533 of "Corynebacterium uratoxydans".
Data are supplemented with our own results on the peptidoglycan, DNA G+C content and some metabolic properties.

In young cultures, straight to slightly curved or ellipsoidal rods with metachromic granules to pleomorphic rods which are club shaped swellings; angular or palisade rods formed by snapping divisions are observed.
Gram-positive; 0.8 to 1.2 by 1.0 to 5 μm; non motile.
No capsula; no endospores.
Colonies circular, flat, smooth, entire margines, slightly glistening and opaque, 3-4 mm in diameter; creamy white in young cultures to pale yellow in old cultures.
Water soluble, pale yellowish brown pigment produced In nutrient broth scanty surface growth; no sediments.
In gelatine stab best growth at top and filiform; liquification stratiform.
In litmus milk no reaction slightly alkaline; no coagulation.
Nitrate reduced to nitrite.

Voges-Proskauer test negative, Indole production negative; hydrogen sulfide production positive; hydrolrsis of starch negative; utilization of sodium citrate (Koser's and Christen's medium) positive; utilization of a great variety of organic nitrogen compounds.
Uricase strongly positive; haemolysis negative; pathology negative.
Utilization of a great variety of organic compounds: besides those listed (see footnote to Table 5), 5-amino valerate, glyoxylate, L-leucine, L-xylose, and uric acid are utilized in addition.
Hydrolysis of xanthine and casein; no acid from sugars; cellulose is not decomposed.
Aerobic to slightly facultative anaerobic; optimal tpetature for growth between 27 and 35 °C; optimal pH for growth between 7 and 8; thermal death time 10' at 52°C.
The peptide subunit of the peptidoglycan consistes of alanine, D-glutamic acid and lysine.
The interpeptide bridge contains alanine and glutamic acid (Lys-Ala-Glu type, variation A4α, according to Schleifer and Kandler, 1972).
The G + C content of the DNA is 61.2 and 61.5 for the strains tested.
Habitar: Humus soil.
Type strain: Arthrobacter uratoxydans ATCC 21749.
Comments: Contradicting results have been found for the acid production.

While strong acid formation from glucose, fructose, and maltose have been reported by Suisaki et al. (1973), no acid production from any sugar tested could be detected in out study. A. uratoxydans can be distinguished from A. nicotianae and A. protophormiae by the strong activity of oxydative decomposition of uric acid and by the lack of ability to utilize L-asparagine, L-arginine, L-histidine, D-xylose, D-ribose, L-arabinose, D-galactose, and glycerol.
Strains of this species are used for the production of uricase (US patent 3.767.533).
